channel.title: Python course
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian

item.title: Dictionaries
item.description:
A simple thing with this function is that you can specify something by something else
For example, like this:
monthconvert = { 'jan': 'January', 'feb': 'February', 'mar': 'March', 'apr': 'April', 'May': 'May', 'June': 'June', 'July': 'July', 'aug': 'August', 'sept': 'September', 'oct': 'October', 'nov': 'November', 'dec': 'December' } print(monthconvert['sept']) Copy

item.title: Functions
item.description:
#Basics
#Basics
This is a basic function:
def say_hi(): print("Hi there") #now call the function say_hi() Copy
Here I've made a function called say_hi. Whenever it's done. You can call it afterwards!

item.title: If statements
item.description:
#Basics
#Basics
is_male = True is_female = False if is_male and is_female: print("Male") print("Female") if is_male and not is_female: print("Male") if is_female and not is_male: print("Female") Copy
This is really basic, but we can add an else function to make it shorter.
This one is better:
is_male = True is_female = False if is_male: print("Male") else: print("Female") Copy
This code checks which number is the biggest, then prints it out
with return statements:
def max_num(num1, num2, num3): if num1 >= num2 and num1 >= num3: return num1 elif num2 >= num1 and num2 >= num3: return num2 elif num3 >= num1 and num3 >= num2: return num3 print(max_num(3, 5, 3)) Copy

item.title: Importing
item.description:
#Basics
#Basics
In python you can import external code:
This allows to do stuff like sqrt (Square root)
from math import * Copy

item.title: Input
item.description:
#Basics
#Basics
Input name and age:
name = input("Enter you name:") print("Hello " + name) age = input("Enter your age:") print("Your age is " + str(age)) Copy

item.title: Lists
item.description:
#Basics
#Basics
You can make a list (basically an array like other languages) like this:
list = [abc, 123, erq, wds] friends = [Jackie, Alan, Yuri] # then you can print them like this: print(friends) Copy
cool stuff:
#adds new in the list friends.append("Bodie") #replaces someone new for example Jackie replaced by Kelly friends.insert(1, "Kelly") #removes jim from the list friends.remove("Alan") #makes list empty friends.clear() #gets rid of the last element of the list friends.pop() #Prints if Kevin is in the list or not (prints out error if false, 0 value if true) print(friends.index("Kevin")) Copy

item.title: Numbers
item.description:
#Basics
#Basics
Rounds up to 5
print(round(4.6)) Copy
Prints out the smallest value
print(min(4.6)) Copy
Prints out the biggest value
print(max(4.6)) Copy
Always rounds UP (for example 4)
print(ceil(3.7)) Copy
Square root (wortel)
print(sqrt(36)) Copy

item.title: Variables
item.description:
#Basics
#Basics
Example
string = Hello World number = 5 print(number) print() Copy

item.title: Calculator version 1
item.description:
#Beginner
#Beginner
So I started doing this at first:
Example 1:
num1 = input("Enter a number: ") num2 = input("Enter another number: ") result = num1 + num2 print(result) Copy
Here in example 1, you can see that the user can enter 2 prompted numbers. For example: The user will enter 2 and 5 as their chosen numbers. The print will be 25.
And that's not what I wanted to achieve so I did this:
Example 2
num1 = input("Enter a number: ") num2 = input("Enter another number: ") result = int(num1) + int(num2) print(result) Copy
In this example, the numbers will be converted into integers. It eventually does the math the correct way by adding up.
If the user enters 2 and 5, the answer would be 7.
But there's one thing and that is that whenever I use decimal numbers, the code will break.
So I decided to convert it to float:
num1 = input("Enter a number: ") num2 = input("Enter another number: ") result = float(num1) + float(num2) print(result) Copy
The final script

item.title: Calculator version 2
item.description:
#Beginner
#Beginner
Just like the previous calculator, but a little better!
num1 = float(input("Enter first number: ")) op = input("Enter operation: ") num2 = float(input("Enter second number: ")) if op == "+": print(num1 + num2) elif op == "-": print(num1 - num2) elif op == "*": print(num1 * num2) elif op == "/": print(num1 / num2) else: print("Invalid operation") Copy
